questionnaire.title: Prevent the Download of Prohibited Mobile Code
Disable User Access to Prohibited Mobile Code Setting
Ensure yum Removes Previous Package Versions
Configure Java Runtime to use System Crypto Policy
The Java deployment.properties File Exists
Disable Execution of Signed Java Applets From Untrusted Sources Setting
Disable User Access to Disabling Untrusted Sources Setting
Enable Java Web Start Applications to Run
Disable User Access to Java Web Start Application Setting
Prompt User Prior to Executing Mobile Code
Disable User Access to Insecure Prompt of Mobile Code Setting
Lock Execution of Signed Java Applets From Untrusted Sources Setting
Disable User Access to Locking Untrusted Sources Setting
Enable Revocation Checks for Publisher Certificates
Disable User Access to Revocation Check Settings
Disable Execution of Unsigned Applications
Disable User Access to Unsigned Applications Setting
Ensure Java Patches Installed
Enable Use of Certificate Revocation Lists
Disable User Access to Certificate Revocation List Settings
Enable Online Certificate Validation
Disable User Access to Online Certificate Validation Setting
The Java exception.sites File Exists
Configure the Path to the exception.sites File
The Java deployment.config File Exists
Configure The Java Deployment Mandatory Setting
Configure the Path to the deployment.properties File

boolean_question.question_text: To verify that Java prevents prohibited mobile code from being downloaded, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.security.blacklist.check=true' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.blacklist.check=true Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that a user cannot change the setting that controls the prevention of downloading prohibited mobile code, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.security.blacklist.check.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.blacklist.check.locked Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that clean_requirements_on_remove is configured properly, run the following command: $ grep clean_requirements_on_remove /etc/yum.conf The output should return something similar to: clean_requirements_on_remove=1 Is it the case that clean_requirements_on_remove is not enabled or configured correctly?

To verify that Java uses the system crypto policy, check out that the respective JRE config file /usr/lib/jvm/jre/lib/security/java.security contains the security.useSystemPropertiesFile=true line: grep 'security.useSystemPropertiesFile=true' /usr/lib/jvm/jre/lib/security/java.security. Is it the case that the 
java.security
doesn't contain the 
security.useSystemPropertiesFile=true
line?
To verify that the deployment.properties file exists, run the following command: $ ls /etc/.java/deployment The output should contain: deployment.properties Is it the case that it does not exist?

To verify that Java cannot execute from untrusted sources, run the following command: $ grep 'askgrantdialog.notinca=false' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.askgrantdialog.notinca=false Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that users cannot change the untrusted sources settings, run the following command: $ grep 'askgrantdialog.notinca.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.askgrantdialog.notinca.locked Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that Java allows applets or Java Web Start (JWS) applications to run, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.webjava.enabled=true' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.webjava.enabled=true Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that a user cannot change the Java Web Start (JWS) application setting, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.webjava.enabled.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.webjava.enabled.locked Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that Java prevents mobile code from executing without prompting the user,run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.insecure.jres=PROMPT' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.insecure.jres=PROMPT Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that a user cannot change the mobile code setting for insecure prompts, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.insecure.jres.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.insecure.jres.locked Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that Java cannot execute from untrusted sources, run the following command: $ grep 'askgrantdialog.show=false' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.askgrantdialog.show=false Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that users cannot change the untrusted sources settings, run the following command: $ grep 'askgrantdialog.show.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.askgrantdialog.show.locked Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that revocation checks are enabled, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.security.revocation.check=' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.revocation.check=ALL_CERTIFICATES Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that users cannot change revocation check settings, run the following command: $ grep 'revocation.check.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.revocation.check.locked Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that Java does not allow unsigned applications to run, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.security.level=VERY_HIGH' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.level=VERY_HIGH Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that a user cannot change the unsigned applications setting, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.security.level.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.level.locked Is it the case that it is not configured?

If the system is joined to the Red Hat Network, a Red Hat Satellite Server, or a yum server which provides updates, invoking the following command will indicate if updates are available: $ sudo yum check-update If the system is not configured to update from one of these sources, run the following command to list when each package was last updated: $ rpm -qa -last Compare this to Red Hat Security Advisories (RHSA) listed at
https://access.redhat.com/security/updates/active/https://access.redhat.com/security/updates/active/ to determine if the system is missing applicable updates. Is it the case that it is not updated?

To verify that the use of Certificate Revocation Lists are enabled, run the following command: $ grep 'validation.crl=true' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.validation.crl=true Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that users cannot change the use of Certificate Revocation List settings, run the following command: $ grep 'validation.crl.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.validation.crl.locked Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that online certificate verification is enabled, run the following command: $ grep 'validation.ocsp=true' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.validation.ocsp=true Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?

To verify that users cannot change online certificate verification, run the following command: $ grep 'validation.ocsp.locked' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.security.validation.ocsp.locked Is it the case that it does not exist or is not configured properly?
To verify that the exception.sites file exists, run the following command: $ ls /etc/.java/deployment The output should contain: exception.sites Is it the case that it does not exist?

To verify that deployment.properties file is configured properly, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.user.security.exception.sites=' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.user.security.exception.sites=/etc/.java/deployment/exception.sites Is it the case that it is not configured?
To verify that the deployment.config file exists, run the following command: $ ls /etc/.java/deployment The output should contain: deployment.config Is it the case that it does not exist?

To verify that deployment.config is configured properly, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.system.config.mandatory' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.config If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.system.config.mandatory=true Is it the case that it is not configured?

To verify that deployment.config is configured properly, run the following command: $ grep 'deployment.system.config=file' /etc/.java/deployment/deployment.config If properly configured, the output should return: deployment.system.config=file:///etc/.java/deployment/deployment.properties Is it the case that it is not configured?
